bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, November 2, 1941

div1.p: Hench sends Truby suggestions for corrections or additions to Truby's manuscript on the story of the yellow fever experiments. He mentions several enclosures, which are not included with this document. An addendum from Hench to Truby on November 10, 1941 is included, as well as a transcription of a letter from James Carroll to his wife.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, November 2, 1941
div1.opener:
Copy for Gen Kean
November 2, 1941
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
I am so sorry that I could not get the following comments to
you sooner but your manuscript reached me at a (for me) very difficult time. I
was in the throes of finishing our annual Rheumatism Review which had to be in
the hands of the Editor of the Annals of Internal Medicine yesterday. By long
hours of work and many headaches I got it off and am just now free to do justice
to your splendid manuscript. It is so very interesting and, without meaning to
reflect on the first interesting version, this copy is a tremendous improvement
over the first one from an editorial and reader's standpoint. As I wrote you it
so fascinated me I read it at one sitting from 10 P.M. to about 2 A.M. one night.

Permit me to send some comments many of which may be of little
or no value, I am afraid, but I hope you will find some helpful, and you will of
course disregard the others.

Title page.--May I suggest that you give further thought to
provide a more arresting title. Some suggestions might be “Memories of my service
in Cuba and of Walter Reed's work, etc.” or “Memories of an army physician (1899-1906)
with Walter Reed in Cuba” or “Personal recollections of Walter Reed and the con-
quest of yellow fever” or “Memories of an army physician in Cuba during the conquest
of yellow fever” with a subtitle “With some personal recollections of Walter Reed”
etc. You may regard some of these titles as more presumptious than your original
title but they are more intriguing and arresting and your reader will consider the
title fully warranted in my opinion.

P. 1.--Since this is frankly an autobiography may I suggest that
in your initial sentence you plunge right in instead of “sliding in sideways”; by
that I mean that to me the first sentence would be improved by being rewritten thus:
“At the beginning of the year 1898 I was a resident physician------etc.

P. 2.--You emphasize and underscore “doctors in good standing”
for reasons which do not become clear till one reads page 3. But until the reader
reads page 3 he will not appreciate the emphasis and may read into your sentence an
unhappy connotation that there were then so many physicians in bad standing that one
had to go out and hunt for someone in good standing. Could you not avoid this im-
plication by saying, “two physicians in good standing--I emphasize this for reasons
which will become obvious....etc.”

P. 7.--Dr. Abbott's course in what? (I see you state what on p.8;
better replace this data or part of it to p. 7.

P. 9.--Why not say, “Capt. A.M. Stark, whom I was to meet so often
later in Cuba, was recorder of the Board. He took us....” etc. This answers the
question that some readers will have. “What Capt. Stark? The one who was later
in Cuba?”

Chapter I. By all means include this chapter. But one thing I
can't understand. In view of the great needs of the army medical corps (as shown
so well on your page 45) why was it so hard for qualified young physicians to get
into the corps? How many army physicians were there in 1899?

P. 12.--These of us (my generation) who see so little typhoid
would like to know what was “the normal (Cuban) civilian death rate.”

P. 14.--“The first ship carrying U. S. troops”--wouldn't it be well
to make it clear that these were troops coming after the fighting to occupy the
island? Many readers will be very hazy about the dates of the war, occupation,
etc.

P. 15.--Can you not insert the date when a British army was wiped out
by sickness in Cuba? Wouldn't almost any detailed history of Cuba in the San
Francisco library give the date?

P. 18.--“Trouble was brewing in Havana.” The reader at p. 18 would not
know what trouble until he reads p. 19.
P. 19.--Will the nonmilitary reader accept the term “foot-marched”?
P. 23.--Shouldn't you make clear that Belascoain was a street?
Many such terms, undefined for the reader, might well be clarified.
P. 25. Col. Randall--what branch of service?
P. 26.--“New cases”--“serious cases”. Of what? typhoid or yellow fever?

P. 26.--Wouldn't it be well to tell here more clearly what and where
Military Hospital #1 was? Many readers will not know the relationship (physical
and professional) between it and Columbia Hosp., Las Animas Hosp., etc.

P. 29.--“...he urged that the mosquito was the agent” etc. Better to
say, “he stated his belief that....etc.” or “he insisted that....”.

I think this would be an excellent place (in view of the continuing con-
troversy) for you, an eye- and war-witness, to here amplify clearly the attitude of
Cuban medicine in 1899 toward Finlay and his ideas.

P. 32.--The remarks inserted in brackets are out of their time relation-
ships hence should be inserted in brackets or parentheses.
P. 32.--“It was Major Reed....” Suggest adding “who had arrived in Havana..”

P. 33.--Suggest change to “....the hospital Terry which was approaching
Havana” or “which ran between Havana and New York(?).”
P. 34.--I have suggested a few changes as marked.

P. 35.--Suggested title for Chapter IV--“We move the troops away from
yellow fever.” All along I think you should personalize your titles even if it
is slightly “distasteful” to you. It is better for the reader, and once you've
decided to write your book, you must put false modesty aside.

P. 36.--You use the term “Columbia Barracks” before using “Camp Columbia.”
Was it called Columbia Barracks when you moved there? If so shouldn't you say:
“When the 7th army corps had occupied this site from __________ to late Spring, 1899
(p. 40) it had become known as Camp Columbia and was known by that name long after
the camp tents had been replaced in _________ by wedden barracks.

P. 36.--Wouldn't it be well to say “sloping gradually to the Gulf of Mexico
whichwas about I mile to the north (or northwest)?”

Inserts after p. 39.--Should the 1902 map be placed ahead of the 1907
map? I see you've drawn in buildings 121 and 122 on the 1902 and the 1907 maps.
In your “key” next to page 40 you identify bldgs. 86-87-88 but they aren't shown
on the portion of the 1902 map which is above the key.

P. 40.--I can verify Dr. Pinto's recollection that the Second Division
Hosp. was on the site later used for Camp Columbia. I wanted to know this and
finally checked it on the old maps in the map department in the Military Hospital,
Havana (present site of Columbia Barracks).

P. 41.--“The sick were cared for in tent wards.” Where? I thought that
they (that is the average run of your cases, not the y.f. cases) were cared for in
bldgs. 91-92-93, i.e. the wooden wards.

P. 43. “A long temporary building”-----why not insert in parentheses the
key number referring to this bldg.? Was it bldg. 122?

P. 45.--Shouldn't some of the data in paragraph 2 be given in Chapter I
instead of here?

P. 46.--“At Military Hosp. #1, too far away.....” etc. As I stated before,
you haven't yet given the uninformed reader an idea of its physical and professional
relationship to Camp Columbia, the city of Havana, etc.

P. 46.--Should you say “the strength of troops in the Department of Cuba
was 3009 of which 1716 were at Columbia Barracks.” Is this correct?

P. 46.--Nonmedical readers won't know that “rate per M” means rate per
thousand.
P. 48.--Shouldn't the last paragraph be postponed for use later?

P. 49.--I would identify the “bachelor's bldg.” with its key number and
tell why it was so called and distinguish it from “bachelor's row”. I did not
realize for a long time that “bachelor's row” didn't mean the row of rooms in the
bachelor's bldg. Many such things confuse the reader who wasn't there in 1900.

P. 52.--The Cubans called it “a yellow fever year”--even before it broke
out. Why? Explain more fully.

P. 59.--Did you know that later in Panama, Lambert and Moran had a serious
personal disagreement. Will tell you of it when I visit S.F. this spring. Can
Lambert's present statements all be accepted without question?

P. 65.--Dr. Pinto says Durham and Myers were in Havana “early in July,”
on page 66 you merely say “July”. In the letters of Reed copies of which his daughter,
Blossom, showed me is one dated July 19, 1900 which starts out “Yesterday we had the
pleasure of entertaining Drs. Durham and Myers, two English physicians who have been
sent out by the School of Tropical Medicine to study yellow fever. They are going
to Brazil, and came down to Havana just to make our acquaintance and to ascertain
what, if anything we had discovered. We have placed our laboratories at their dis-
posal during the ten days they will be in Havana. (D. and M. stayed at the La
Florida Hotel.)” etc. Reed's previous letter home was dated July 13 and made no
mention of Durham or Myers. Reed's next letter was dated July 30. Can't one assume
that D. and M. arrived in Havana on or about July 18 and left about July 28? Reed
makes no mention of them in his letter of July 30 which describes his plans to leave
Havana on the Rawlins about July 31 or Aug. 1.

This seems to be borne out by statements made in a letter Reed sent from
Quemados July 24, 1900 to Gen. Sternberg in which he wrote “Drs. Durham and Meyers
(sic) arrived about a week ago........They sail for New York on Saturday next.”
My 1900 calendar would indicate this to be Sat. July 28. In a letter Reed wrote
from Washington to Maj. Kean in Cuba June 5, 1901 he wrote, “Durham has come to
town.” This gives the date of a later visit to the U. S., of course.

P. 71. Are you sure that “Agramonte returned” to Havana from Pinar del
Rio and that Reed went back with him? Your version contradicts that of Agramonte
(Scientific Monthly, Dec. 1915, page 217-218). Unfortunately for your version Agra-
monte's is uphold by published telegrams sent by Stark from Quemados. One dated
July 20 to Agramonte thanks Agramonte for his telegraphic report; another dated
July 21 from Stark to Agramonte (at Pinar) says, “Take charge of cases. Reed goes on
morning train.....etc.” Obviously Agramonte stayed at Pinar, Reed went there to
meet him and arrived at Pinar July 21. Your date July 31 is I assume taken from the
Senate Document 822 page 93 line 11 which in turn was taken from Reed's article in
Medical Record 60: 201-209; Aug. 10, 1901. But this date July 31 was an error
(Gen. Kean agrees with me in this) and you will note that 4 lines later (Sen. Dec.
p. 93 line 15) Reed used the date July 21. In Senate Document page 25 note Agramonte's
additional statement that he “was joined there [in Pinar] by Maj. Reed a couple of
days later.”

You have warned me to be careful about accepting Agramonte's statements but
in this instance the copies of Stark's telegrams seem to certify Agramonte's statements.

P. 82.--You don't tell here (or on page 80) the date of your arrival at
Columbia Barracks.

P. 83.--Dr. Pinto says Carroll was in the first hut south of Ames' quarters.
Lazear was not put in these quarters but the next one to it. Does that mean that
Carroll was in bldg. 116 and Lazear in #118? The word “south” doesn't look right.
See 1902 map (preceding page 40) and what was “the next one to” Ames' quarters?
This is sentimentally an important point. If we know this we could even now identify
the very spot where Lazear died.

P. 83.--There were “Lazear's quarters”?--in the bachelor's quarters, in the
bachelor's row? His wife wasn't there at this time; had he given up his quarters
in bldg, 106?

P. 85.--You say: “..the body of Dr. Lazear was the last yellowfever case
from the Post or Quemados to be interred in our cemetery.” I think this is wrong.
From the National Archives I got the list of interments and disinterments at the
Post Cemetery between 1899 and Jan. 1901. Lazear was buried Sept. 26, 1900 (in-
terment #138). Civilian clerk Ferguson was buried the same day, Private Parks 2 days
later and at least 13 more privates, clerks, etc. were buried between Oct. 1 and
Dec. 22. These included Maj. and Mrs. Peterson (Oct. 18), Capt. Page (Oct. 27) and
Hospital Steward Halstead (Nov. 23). At least some of these had yellow fever.
Via Truby 11/20/41

P. 8884.--Dr. Pinto says: “Ames was very much disturbed and spoke to me
several times about Carroll not having visited Lazear during his sickness.” But
on page 84 although you say Gorgas and Kean were the only ones from the outside
(better clarify) who saw Lazear, Lazear “told both Gorgas and Carroll etc.” Thus
your last statement seems to contradict that of Dr. Pinto. Did Carroll visit Lazear
after Lazear became sick but before Lazear was taken to sick-quarters?

P. 88.--I am much surprised by your statement that Reed didn't know of
Lazear's death on Sept. 25 until he learned it Oct. 3 from Harvard and Kean at
Matanzas. You say Reed's transport had “sailed from New York on Sept. 25th.”
But Gen. Kean (to my delight) gave me a letter written to him by Dr. Reed. It is
- 5 -
dated Sept. 25, 1900 and was written on the stationary of the War Dept; Surgeon
General's office, Washington. Of course it need not have been mailed from Washington
but it seems to have been as Reed said “I have now only just returned from my outing
in the hills of Pa. and am so distressed to hear that Lazear is down with yellow fever.
The General handed me your cable yesterday afternoon as soon as I entered his office.
I shall await your next with much anxiety....” “I have engaged passage on the Crook
which sails next Friday 28th and should reach Havana on October 2nd or 3rd.” General
Kean's diary says he met Reed Wed. Oct. 3 at Matanzas when the Crook stopped there.
Apparently Reed reached Havana Oct. 4. Kean's diary does not indicate that Reed did
not yet know of Lazear's death. It merely reads “He is much grieved over Lazear's
death.” (I have checked a 1900 calendar - Oct. 3, 1900 was Wed.)

Reed's letters to the Adj. Gen. reporting his whereabouts (in National
Archives) report that he was:
Sept. 1 - Sept. 25, 1900--Curator Army Med. Museum.

Sept. 26 - Sept. 30--enrouts from Washington to Havana (report dated Nov. 10,
1900 from Havana)
Oct. 1 - 13--at Camp Columbia (report dated S G O Oct. 31)
Oct.14-- 20--enroute U. S.

These may have been his formal whereabouts but he seems not to have left
and arrived just as here stated.

In his Scientific Monthly article page 219 Agramonte said that “Reed was
detained longer than he expected and could not return to Cuba until early in October
several days after Lazear's death.”

Obviously when Reed wrote to Kean on Sept. 25 he had not yet heard of
Lazear's death but it certainly seems that he did not leave from New York on Sept.
25 and that he did hear of Lazear's death before he left the U. S. Perhaps he didn't
hear the details of Lazear's death until he met Maj. Kean at Matanzas.

P. 90.--The description in your first manuscript of Reed's eager study
of Lazear's notebook seemed to me (as I remember it) more dramatic than your present
version given in the last paragraph of this page. Haven't you changed your first
description, “softened it down”? Perhaps you haven't changed it at all and my
memory plays me a trick. Perhaps it was my first reading (rather than your first
version) that was more dramatic to me.

P. 91.--Did you ask Pinto to criticize Agramonte's version of Dean's
inoculation as given in Scientific Monthly, Dec. 1915, page 210 (note the supposed
conversation between Dean and Lazear) and Agramonte's essentially similar statements
elsewhere; in Annals Int. Med. Aug. 1928, Vol. 2, page 149, where Agramonte says “as
several mosquitoes took blood from (Dean's) forearm I noted on a slip of paper the
necessary data” also in Military Surgeon, Nov. 1930, Vol. 67, page 561 a similar
statement. I think I sent you a copy of Agramonte's scathing letter to Hemmeter
dated Feb. 2, 1913 in which Agramonte wrote “As the mosquito filled with blood, I
came to the door and asked the man (Dean) when he had been away from camp the last
time, to which he answered, ‘Oh, about two months.’ This is how the second case was
produced and all else is pure fancy.” Are you going to comment on this oft-repeated
version? You know of A's other statements which I uncovered which indicated that
A. knew nothing of at least the first and probably the first two inoculations until
Lazear told him afterwards. It seems to me you should check this carefully with
Pinto and if he supports your views you should somehow (diplomatically if possible)
contradict this oft-repeated version. It isn't fair to us who weren't there
- 6 -
(historians of the future) to have to contradict this entirely without the support
of those of you who were there and who refute it. Or let me put it another way.
You could help us greatly by somehowi stating your difference of opinion. I realize
you hate to get into an argument but I believe you can state your belief in terms
which will not be offensive to Miss Agramonte and her friends. You know of course
of Kissinger's version that Dean was an impolite scoffing soldier who had kidded
Lazear and that Lazear later put the mosquitoes on Dean while the latter slept. Are
you going to disregard this version entirely also and not deny it?

P. 96.--“Lazear's statement to him (Carroll).” But this contradicts
Pinto's statement which you apparently intend to insert on page 88.

P. 98.--“Agramonte absent from Havana”.... Are you absolutely sure?
Despite Carroll's letter to his wife suggesting that Agramonte was absent from
Havana when Lazear died it seems difficult to believe it and both Mrs. Lazear and
Miss Agramonte refuse to believe it. As both pointed out it is most difficult to
believe that with Reed away, Carroll still convalescing and Lazear sick that Agra-
monte could have gotten permission to leave also. In Agramonte's article in
Military Surgeon, Nov. 1930 page 562 he says about Lazear's illness: “Carroll was
yet convalescing and Reed was still in Washington striving to return to Havana.
I need not tell you of the sleepless nights, the worry and the heart pangs of that
week. In the short intervals of respite from his fever and delerium Lazear assured
us.......etc. On Sept. 26 we buried him” etc.

In Mrs. Lazear's letter to me Feb. 14, 1941 she said “I certainly think
it's a mistake about Dr. Agramonte being away from Cuba at the time of my husband's
death, for one reason especially, that in everything Dr. Agramonte wrote, he actually
stated he was there. Then I feel sure that two of the doctors would not have been
allowed to go away at the same time, and as you know Dr. Reed was in this country.....
There is a possibility Dr. Carroll made a slip and meant to write someone else's name.”

In a letter to Mrs. Lazear written July 15, 1930 (I have photostat)
Agramonte wrote: “He was my classmate, as you may know, and every moment of our
contact at Camp Columbia is still vivid in my mind, until the moment of his passing
away at the hospital, which day I shall never forget as long as I live.”

Since you and I have both noted other definite errors in Carroll's letters
(see your page 100) is it not possible Carroll mispoke here also? I plan to check
Agramonte's record of service (absences, departures, etc.) if I can find it in Wash-
ington. I found that of Reed but I wonder if contract surgeons had to report as
carefully as did regular officers. But somewhere in Washington Agramonte's leaves
are certainly available. I intend to go to Washington in January. If you will tell
me where to go for this data I'll go there.

P. 99.--I enclose Carroll's letter to his wife as published by Hemmeter
in Janus but as stated above I think it errs. It is true that in his letter to
Hemmetor Agramonte neglected to deny this statement of Carroll, but A. was denying
what H. was saying and not what C. said; furthermore A. said to K. that he was
answering only “the most flagrant errors,” and by no means all of them.
P. 100.--Small correction made.

P. 101.--In Reed's letter to sternberg, Oct. 22, 1900, you copy it as
published----“from the history of T. C. Y”. From a study of old handwriting I
think I can explain that. Obviously it should read “from the history of XY.” What
happened was that Reed wrote the X this way [unclear] which someone read as T.G.

P. 103.--Is it “Dougherty wagon” or “doherty wagon”? I've seen it
spelled both ways.

P. 105.--Was Gen. Baker's article ever published? I'm very glad to
get this story and the toast mentioned on page 107. I mentioned this toast in my
Hygeia article having gotten it from Hagedorn who did not mention Gen. Baker or give
the source of the story.

P. 108.--I am very anxious to know how much you yourself actually had to do
with the construction of Camp Lazear. I think you told me you helped considerably.
How often did you visit it, alone or with Reed, during its construction? Did you
yourself inspect the inside of Bldgs. 1 or 2? Could you give me a letter amplifying
your remark about my photos of the inside of bldg. 1. You wrote me that without
doubt we'd found Bldg. 1. A letter from you would help me with doubters.
P. 115.--Folk's name is misspelled.

P. 119.--“Ames was selected to run the camp”--“he continued to live in a
tent at Camp Lazear.” I know that on page 71 Senate Doc. Reed, Carroll and Agramonte
said: “The personnel of this camp (Lazear) consisted of two medical officers, Dr.
Roger P. Ames--in immediate charge.” But Moran emphatically disputed this to me
more than once. He said that Ames stayed at Columbia Barracks all the time taking
care of the cases of experimental yellow fever at the yellow fever huts. Moran never
saw Ames at Camp Lazear while he (Moran) was there. Cooke was the only officer there
but since Cooke was a volunteer for experiments there was really no resident physician
in charge at Camp Lazear constantly. But Reed came out at least twice daily. That is
Moran's version to me. Could it be that Ames was not in residence at Camp Lazear
while Moran was there but was there later after Moran got yellow fever and was removed
to the yellow fever huts? Surely we could check this with Andrus, England or others.

P. 122.--I think the title is fine. Suggest spelling it correctly but use
it in quotes anyhow.

P. 132.--You say that “from Dec. 15 until Dec. 25 no cases developed in
camp since no volunteers were bitten. This hiatus in the experimental work was to
show that the camp was not infected.” I've never seen this explanation in any of the
Board's papers. I wonder if it is correct. I'm inclined to think not. The “hiatus”
was probably accidental. Presedo was bitten Dec. 11 and got sick Dec. 15. “About
this time there was a panic among the Spanish volunteers. Many of them fled and quit
the camp.” See Reed's paper as cited on p. 99, Senate Doc., also Agramonte's Scientific
Monthly article page 235. “Our artificial epidemic of yellow fever was temporarily
suspended while a new batch of susceptible material was brought in, observed and
selected.” In other words the hiatus was accidental (lack of volunteers) and not
deliberate. As a matter of fact Martinez was bitten on Dec. 17 (without results).

P. 133.--“I with other nonimmunes”--you saw a copy of my letter to Miss
Wood as to my researches on who and how many these nonimmunes were. Statements are
contradictory but I think my letter to Miss Wood is correct. There were probably five
persons present besides Moran. (See copy of my Sept. 19, 1941 letter to Miss Wood).
P. 140.--Was this Andrus?

P. 144.--Are you going to sidestep the controversy entirely? You may be
the last living eye-witness to write his experiences. Regardless of your distaste
- 8 -
for the controversy don't you owe it to present and future readers to straighten them
out on certain facts of which youare so sure and certain opinions which you hold so
firmly? I think you should and can do it diplomatically.

Let me say again what a privilege it has been to read the manuscript. I
do hope you will send it to publishers with a larger clientele than that of the
Carlisle Army Bulletin but at any rate it must be published. As you have instructed
me I am sending your manuscript to Gen. Kean with two carbons of this letter in
case he wants to keep one and to make notes for you on the other. I am sending to
you some data Gen. Kean loaned me and asked me to send you to return to him when you
have studied it.

May I append a list of photographs which I think would be good illustra-
tions to your book. Probably you could obtain them all from the army files.

list.item:
1. To illustrate chapter 1 - Photo of old Army Medical School as of 1898.
Photo of your examining board?

2. For page 14 - photo of entrance to Havana Harbor as of 1898. Think I
have seen such a photo (U.S. Army Signal Corps) in official reports
of Gov. Gen. of Cuba.
3. For page 15.--Wreck of Maine (Signal corps photo).

4. P. 18 - Hotel Trocha as of 1941 (if you wish my negative). Your con-
temporaries might like to see the old hotel for old times' sake.

5. P. 20 - Old army photo showing transfer of Cuba from Spanish to U.S.
rule. Photo of departing Spanish soldiers. Have seen these in
Gov. Gen'l's reports.
6. P. 24 - Small photo of old fort and Spanish Barracks at La Punts.

7. P. 25 - Would you like my negative (1941) of Albertini and Moran or
Miss Agramonte's photo of Finlay, Guiteras, Albertini et al.

8. P. 38.- Group or individual photos of your chief colleagues at Columbia
Barracks (several aren't in the group on the stairs).
9. P. 76. Photo of Rawlins from Gov. Gen. Report.

10. Insert somewhere your photo of Dr. and Mrs. Lazear et al. I hope you
can get the model at Carlisle photographed properly.

div1.closer:
Very sincerely, Enclosures:
1. Copy of my letter to Miss Wood, Sept. 19, 1941.
2. Agramonte's Scientific Monthly Dec. 1915 article.
3. Agramonte's letter to Hemmeter, Feb. 2, 1913.
4. 1899 map I found in Havana. Hope you can read it with a magnifying glass.
I think you already have a photo of the 2nd Division Hospital; I think I
sent you one; use it by all means.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, November 10, 1941
div1.p:
In your letter of September 3, 1941 you suggest that when I go to
Washington in January I search for the original official records of the sick
and wounded at Columbia Post Hospital from Aug. 1900 to March 1901 with case
reports of Dean, etc. Where would I be likely to find these, in the Surgeon
General's office?

Remember my offer to lend you an English translation (I had it bound)
of Dominguez' book. Would you like to read it soon?

Gen. Kean informs me that the Captain who in June to Oct. 1901 signed
some of the sanitary reports of the Post Hospital was Capt. Edward F. Horr, Vol.
Med. Officer on duty at Columbia Barracks for ashort time.

Kellogg and I checked with the Pension Bureau the spelling of the
names--the correct spelling are Olson and Weatherwalks although certain “official”
documents spell them Olsen and Weatherwalk.

I see I haven't commented on your suggestion to submit your manuscript
to Fishbein. I do not know how often the A.M.A. publishes nontechnical books,
very rarely I believe. “The Life of Sternberg” is about the only one I know of in
recent years. But it would certainly do no harm to submit it to Fishbein. He might
give some very valuable suggestions.

Did Gen. Kean tell you of Lambert's recent attempts (1940) to get on
the roll of honor? He has been trying to get on since 1928. Col. Love in a
letter to Gen. Kean (July 8, 1940) said that the House Committee had reported
favorably on the bill. I don't know what occurred thereafter.

div1.head: Letter from James Carroll to Jennie Carroll, September 23, 1900
div1.opener:
Letter of Dr. Carroll to his wife published by Hemmeter in Janus 1908 page 164-165
Camp Columbia, Quemados, Cuba
Sunday, Sept. 23, 1900
My dear Jennie:
div1.p:
I write this to let you know that I am still alive and gaining
strength. I look forward to morrow's (sic) mail for some news from Doctor
Reed as I have not heard a word from him and do not know what to expect.
Agramonte left for New York yesterday with his wife and Doctor Lazear is
still very ill with about even chances for his recovery. Mayor Cartwright
who was the next to take yellow fever after me, died this morning. I asked
for an autopsy and it was refused. Doctor John Guiteras, formerly Professor
of Pathology at the University of Pa. called to see me this afternoon as also
did Dr. Gorgas and Dr. Finley (sic). Everybody is surprised at the manner in
which I am picking up flesh ad (sic) strength and all these yellow fever
experts remarked how strong I was upon my legs. Yellow fever has no terrors
for me now, because I am an immune and cannot contract it again, which gives
me a great feeling of comfort....................
